# Lab: Axes manipulation {#sec-axes-manipulation} One way to create potentially misleading visualisations is by manipulating the axes of a plot. Here we illustrate these using one of the FiveThirtyEight data sets, which are available [here](https://data.fivethirtyeight.com). ## Data wrangling We are going to use polls from the recent USA presidential election. As before, we load and examine the data. ::: {.cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import seaborn as sns import altair as alt df_polls = pd.read_csv('data/presidential_poll_averages_2020.csv') df_polls.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=1} ```{=html}
cycle state modeldate candidate_name pct_estimate pct_trend_adjusted
0 2020 Wyoming 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 30.81486 30.82599
1 2020 Wisconsin 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 52.12642 52.09584
2 2020 West Virginia 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 33.49125 33.51517
3 2020 Washington 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 59.34201 59.39408
4 2020 Virginia 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 53.74120 53.72101
``` ::: ::: For our analysis, we are going to pick estimates from 11/3/2020 for the swing states of Florida, Texas, Arizona, Michigan, Minnesota and Pennsylvania. ::: {.cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_nov = df_polls[ (df_polls.modeldate == '11/3/2020') ] df_nov = df_nov[ (df_nov.candidate_name == 'Joseph R. Biden Jr.') | (df_nov.candidate_name == 'Donald Trump') ] df_swing = df_nov[ (df_nov['state'] == 'Florida') | (df_nov['state'] == 'Texas' ) | (df_nov['state'] == 'Arizona' ) | (df_nov['state'] == 'Michigan' ) | (df_nov['state'] == 'Minnesota' ) | (df_nov['state'] == 'Pennsylvania' ) ] df_swing ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=2} ```{=html}

7 2020 Texas 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 47.46643 47.44781
12 2020 Pennsylvania 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 50.22000 50.20422
30 2020 Minnesota 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 51.86992 51.84517
31 2020 Michigan 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 51.17806 51.15482
46 2020 Florida 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 49.09162 49.08035
53 2020 Arizona 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 48.72237 48.70539
63 2020 Texas 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 48.57118 48.58794
68 2020 Pennsylvania 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 45.57216 45.55034
86 2020 Minnesota 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 42.63638 42.66826
87 2020 Michigan 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 43.20577 43.23326
102 2020 Florida 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 46.68101 46.61909

``` ::: ::: ## Default barplot We can look at the relative performance of the candidates within each state using a nested bar plot. ::: {.cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} ax = sns.barplot( data = df_swing, x = 'state', y = 'pct_estimate', hue = 'candidate_name') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_6_2-AxisManipulation_files/figure-pdf/cell-4-output-1.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: ## Altering the axes Altering the axis increases the distance between the bars. Some might say that is misleading. ::: {.cell execution_count=4} ``` {.python .cell-code} ax = sns.barplot( data = df_swing, x = 'state', y = 'pct_estimate', hue = 'candidate_name') ax.set(ylim=(41, 52)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=4} ``` [(41.0, 52.0)] ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_6_2-AxisManipulation_files/figure-pdf/cell-5-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: What do you think? How about if we instead put the data on the full 0 to 100 scale? ::: {.cell execution_count=5} ``` {.python .cell-code} ax = sns.barplot( data = df_swing, x = 'state', y = 'pct_estimate', hue = 'candidate_name') ax.set(ylim=(0, 100)) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=5} ``` [(0.0, 100.0)] ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](IM939_Lab_6_2-AxisManipulation_files/figure-pdf/cell-6-output-2.pdf){fig-pos='H'} ::: ::: We can do the same thing in Altair. ::: {.cell execution_count=6} ``` {.python .cell-code} alt.Chart(df_swing).mark_bar().encode( x='candidate_name', y='pct_estimate', color='candidate_name', column = alt.Column('state:O', spacing = 5, header = alt.Header(labelOrient = "bottom")), ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=6} ``` alt.Chart(...) ``` ::: ::: Note the need for the alt column. What happens if you do not provide an alt column? Passing the domain option to the scale of the Y axis allows us to choose the y axis range. ::: {.cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} alt.Chart(df_swing).mark_bar().encode( x='candidate_name', y=alt.Y('pct_estimate', scale=alt.Scale(domain=[42,53])), color='candidate_name', column = alt.Column('state:O', spacing = 5, header = alt.Header(labelOrient = "bottom")), ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=7} ``` alt.Chart(...) ``` ::: ::: ## Altering the proportions We can even be a bit tricky and stretch out the difference. ::: {.cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} alt.Chart(df_swing).mark_bar().encode( x='candidate_name', y=alt.Y('pct_estimate', scale=alt.Scale(domain=[42,53])), color='candidate_name', column = alt.Column('state:O', spacing = 5, header = alt.Header(labelOrient = "bottom")), ).properties( width=20, height=600 ) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=8} ``` alt.Chart(...) ``` ::: ::: ## Default line plot It is not just bar plot that you can have fun with. Line plots are another interesting example. For our simple line plot, we will need the poll data for a single state. ::: {.cell execution_count=9} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_texas = df_polls[ df_polls['state'] == 'Texas' ] df_texas_bt = df_texas[ (df_texas['candidate_name'] == 'Donald Trump') | (df_texas['candidate_name'] == 'Joseph R. Biden Jr.') ] df_texas_bt.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=9} ```{=html}
cycle state modeldate candidate_name pct_estimate pct_trend_adjusted
7 2020 Texas 11/3/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 47.46643 47.44781
63 2020 Texas 11/3/2020 Donald Trump 48.57118 48.58794
231 2020 Texas 11/2/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 47.46643 47.44781
287 2020 Texas 11/2/2020 Donald Trump 48.57118 48.58794
455 2020 Texas 11/1/2020 Joseph R. Biden Jr. 47.45590 47.43400
``` ::: ::: The modeldate column is a string (object) and not date time. So we need to change that: we will create a new datetime column called `modeldate`. ::: {.cell execution_count=10} ``` {.python .cell-code} #df_texas_bt.loc[df_texas_bt[]] ``` ::: ::: {.cell execution_count=11} ``` {.python .cell-code} print('Before\n') print(df_texas_bt.dtypes) df_texas_bt['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_texas_bt.loc[:,'modeldate'], format='%m/%d/%Y').copy() print('\nAfter\n') print(df_texas_bt.dtypes) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout} ``` Before cycle int64 state object modeldate object candidate_name object pct_estimate float64 pct_trend_adjusted float64 dtype: object After cycle int64 state object modeldate object candidate_name object pct_estimate float64 pct_trend_adjusted float64 date datetime64[ns] dtype: object ``` ::: ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr} ``` /var/folders/7v/zl9mv52s3ls94kntlt_l9ryh0000gq/T/ipykernel_41394/3228356118.py:3: SettingWithCopyWarning: A value is trying to be set on a copy of a slice from a DataFrame. Try using .loc[row_indexer,col_indexer] = value instead See the caveats in the documentation: https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/user_guide/indexing.html#returning-a-view-versus-a-copy df_texas_bt['date'] = pd.to_datetime(df_texas_bt.loc[:,'modeldate'], format='%m/%d/%Y').copy() ``` ::: ::: Create our line plot. ::: {.cell execution_count=12} ``` {.python .cell-code} alt.Chart(df_texas_bt).mark_line().encode( y=alt.Y('pct_estimate', scale=alt.Scale(domain=[42,53])), x='date', color='candidate_name') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=12} ``` alt.Chart(...) ``` ::: ::: Sometimes multiple axis are used for each line, or in a combined line and bar plot. The example [here](https://altair-viz.github.io/user_guide/scale_resolve.html) uses a dataframe with a column for each line. Our data does not have that. ::: {.cell execution_count=13} ``` {.python .cell-code} df_texas_bt our_df = df_texas_bt[['candidate_name', 'pct_estimate', 'date']] our_df ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=13} ```{=html}

``` ::: ::: Pivot table allows us to reshape our dataframe. ::: {.cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} our_df = pd.pivot_table(our_df, index=['date'], columns = 'candidate_name') our_df.columns = our_df.columns.to_series().str.join('_') our_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=14} ```{=html}
pct_estimate_Donald Trump pct_estimate_Joseph R. Biden Jr.

``` ::: ::: Date here is the dataframe index. We want it to be a column. ::: {.cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} our_df['date1'] = our_df.index our_df.columns = ['Trump', 'Biden', 'date1'] our_df.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=15} ```{=html}
Trump Biden date1

2020-03-02 48.91861 45.37694 2020-03-02
``` ::: ::: Creating our new plot, to fool all those people who expect Trump to win in Texas. ::: {.cell execution_count=16} ``` {.python .cell-code} base = alt.Chart(our_df).encode( alt.X('date1') ) line_A = base.mark_line(color='#5276A7').encode( alt.Y('Trump', axis=alt.Axis(titleColor='#5276A7'), scale=alt.Scale(domain=[42,53])) ) line_B = base.mark_line(color='#F18727').encode( alt.Y('Biden', axis=alt.Axis(titleColor='#F18727'), scale=alt.Scale(domain=[35,53])) ) alt.layer(line_A, line_B).resolve_scale(y='independent') ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=16} ``` alt.LayerChart(...) ``` ::: ::: Did you see what I did there? Of course, mixed axis plots are rarely purely line plots. Instead they can be mixes of different axis. For these and other plotting mistakes, the economist has a nice article [here](https://medium.economist.com/mistakes-weve-drawn-a-few-8cdd8a42d368). You may want to try some of these plots with this data set or the world indicators dataset from a few weeks ago.
